docs.lead_paragraph: Crisis pregnancy centers in California are in a battle with the state over a new law requiring them to post a notice that free or low-cost abortion care is available.

headline.main: Pregnancy Clinics Fight for Right to Deny Abortion Information
headline.print_headline: Pregnancy Clinics Fight for Right to Deny Abortion Information

docs.abstract: Crisis pregnancy centers in California are engaged in legal battle with state over law requiring them to post notice stating that free or low-cost abortion, contraception and prenatal care are provided to low-income women through public programs; clinics are run by those who oppose abortion on religious grounds, and they argue that law violates their First Amendment right to free speech.
docs.snippet: Crisis pregnancy centers in California are in a battle with the state over a new law requiring them to post a notice that free or low-cost abortion care is available.

docs.lead_paragraph: Christy O'Donnell, a single mother with lung cancer who became a prominent figure in the California right-to-die debate, has died. She was 47.

headline.main: Brother: Right-To-Die Advocate Christy O'Donnell Dies
headline.print_headline: Brother: Right-To-Die Advocate Christy O'Donnell Dies

docs.snippet: Christy O'Donnell, a single mother with lung cancer who became a prominent figure in the California right-to-die debate, has died. She was 47.

docs.lead_paragraph: Breaking with a 41-year-old tradition, the Republican chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees said they would not invite the president’s budget director to testify on the proposal.

headline.main: Congressional Republicans Balk at Obama’s Budget, Sight Unseen
headline.print_headline: Republicans Balk Early at Obama Budget

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans refuse to review Pres Obama's 2017 final budget request with Office and Management and Budget Director Shaun Donovan, breaking with 41-year-old tradition; move offers sign that Obama's proposed initiatives are unlikely to prevail.
docs.snippet: Breaking with a 41-year-old tradition, the Republican chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees said they would not invite the president’s budget director to testify on the proposal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Contamination has turned up in scores of communities in recent years, and experts cite holes in the safety net of rules and procedures.

headline.main: Unsafe Lead Levels in Tap Water Not Limited to Flint
headline.print_headline: Holes in Safety Net Let Contaminants in Water

docs.abstract: Researchers and public health officials warn inadequate coverage of clean-water laws, along with lax enforcement of safety rules and procedures, allow lead and other harmful contaminants into drinking water in cities and communities across United States; efforts to address shortcomings often encounter push-back from industries like agriculture and mining that fear cost increases, and from politicians ideologically opposed to government regulation.
docs.snippet: Contamination has turned up in scores of communities in recent years, and experts cite holes in the safety net of rules and procedures.

byline.contributor: Doris Burke and Alain Delaquérière contributed research.
byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES and JOHN SCHWARTZ

docs.lead_paragraph: When executive board members of the World Health Organization sat down for their annual meeting in Geneva in January, many powerful figures spoke forcefully of the need to reform the leading global authority on health and disease.

headline.main: Special Report-The World Health Organization's Critical Challenge: Healing Itself
headline.print_headline: Special Report-The World Health Organization's Critical Challenge: Healing Itself

docs.snippet: When executive board members of the World Health Organization sat down for their annual meeting in Geneva in January, many powerful figures spoke forcefully of the need to reform the leading global authority on health and disease.
